print_settings.Notes:: All parts designed to be printed with 100% infill. This is important because the material gets really different properties depending on the internal structure. For example, a piece with thin walls and an infill-mesh will be stiff but brittle, it will crack and delaminate easily, while a part which is completely hollow but with thicker solid walls will be much tougher but somewhat flexible. In this application, the latter properties are important for strength. A good example is the track joiners, if you print them with less than 100% infill, they will easily break when you try to disassemble the track layout, but if you print them 100% solid, they can take a lot of twisting and bending.

title: Arc bridge and slope for OS-Railway

description.text:
This page contains both the arc bridge and the slope. This is a massive bridge! it has an 80cm span! :) It uses 4pcs 200mm standard track, which you find on the general track page: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2146361

IMPORTANT! Use 100% infill. The arc pieces are already hollowed out. Less than 100% infill will most likely cause structural problems.

This is a somewhat more experimental print than my others, and it will require some more sanding and tinkering to get it working. As you can see, the picture prototype version differs somewhat from the STL's. I've tried to fix some issues. For obvious reasons I'm not printing more copies of this one my self but I'm pretty sure I have fixed most issues (I hope) :) On the prototype, I tried 1mm thick walls on some parts but that didn't work, they cracked very easily when I tried to assemble the arc. The pieces with 2mm walls however held together perfect, so I've updated the design so that all pieces have 2mm wall thickness.

The arc members all have fastening holes for track supports and the joiner piece. I used only two joiners between the arcs as you might see on the pictures, I include 4pcs in the ready build plates, you can print more if you like but they aren't needed for structural integrity. also if you want to use more supports from the arc down to the track you need to make new ones with adapted lengths. I've included the two lengths that I used in this build, the positions match the track joints where the support is really needed.

Things you need to know about the slope
The slope parts are designed to be glued. (you can screw the track holder joint and the holder plate but personally I think that's a waste of screws, I used melt glue). The position isn't critical at all, that is why I haven't made any guiding parts on the structure. I tried keeping print time to a minimum.

The pillars are already hollowed out! so don't reduce infill, use 100%!

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,25mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Buildplate 2 and 3 of the bridge will need support for the slide-in-ends. (Support from build plate)

All parts designed to be printed with 100% infill. This is important because the material gets really different properties depending on the internal structure. For example, a piece with thin walls and an infill-mesh will be stiff but brittle, it will crack and delaminate easily, while a part which is completely hollow but with thicker solid walls will be much tougher but somewhat flexible. In this application, the latter properties are important for strength. A good example is the track joiners, if you print them with less than 100% infill, they will easily break when you try to disassemble the track layout, but if you print them 100% solid, they can take a lot of twisting and bending.

If you have trouble assembing the track, check if there are some edges that sticks out. It's common if you have a squeezed first layer that you might get a tiny edge where that layer is wider. Going over the part with sanding paper or a file (or knife) will fix this.
Designed using Fusion 360

comments.text: How wide is this? Can this support G-scale / G gauge?
comments.author: RockSolid

comments.text: HI!  I don't see a problem with scaling it up, it just requires a bit of tinkering. First of all you need to pay attention to the distance between the pillars, it's now 80mm and I don't know how much width G-scale requires on average (and I don't mean track width, I mean for the rolling stock). I also suppose you are not going to use an upscaled version of my track so you need to remove the track fasteners but that should not be a biggie. One thing you need to keep in mind though is that the track is a part of the structure in this bridge. The track takes pulling force so that the arc member joints only need to take compression force and not bending force. This is what makes this bridge strong and capable of handling several kilos without problem. If you remove that part and just place the track free, and if base pillars can move away from each other, the arc will be subjected to forces it's not designed to handle. You could of course overcome this by just placing something else between the base pillars or fixing them to the surface, that will give the same effect that the track has on my original design. Also keep in mind if you up-scale that some parts might get too big for your print bed, but the "wires" hanging down from the arc can be replaced by something else so you don't need to use those if they get too long. Good luck and please share a picture if you make an up-scaled version, would love to see that! :)
comments.author: RockSolid

comments.text: I love this bridge Depronized!  Keep up the good work!  I've added a container stand for your container and posted it today.
comments.author: gfrantz

comments.text: Thanks! :) Let me know if you print the bridge, as stated I did some fixes to it so would be nice to know if it works OK. Mine was a disaster, 1mm walls and press fit was not a good idea, all joints with 1mm walls cracked the first time I assembled it so had to put tape around, but the first joint between the base pillars and the first segment is 2mm wall and that held together perfect despite a lot of torture to get the arc segment in place. This is why I changed to 2mm walls all over, so it's really important not to cut down on infill, the walls needs to be solid.

description.text:

author: PIEngr

description.text:
Acquire 2 x 3/16" x 1/4" spring pins - solder wire onto the spring pins. Preferably red and black for positive and ground. POSITIVE IS TOWARDS THE POINTY END - I assume no responsibility if you don't do additional research and smoke your $1500 DI2 buildout. Hell I don't assume any responsibility regardless.

Print Thing 3 and the cap.

Insert the spring pins with attached wires into the cap, run wiring through the non-cap peice, Solder appropriate plug into wires - in my case I used a 3 pin male JS2 connector, which connects to a standard (and optionally very high MAH) 2 cell 7.4v battery.

Adapter should snugly fit into your DI2 battery mount, after which you can run a zip-tie through the center slot to secure it together..

Images shown is my complete working setup (it's been in use for many months) with a custom built 11000mah 7.4v battery.

Let me know if there are any questions.
Planet Express building from Futurama.

description.text:
For months I have been wanting a drone, so I figured I should 3D Print one. I tried looking for some, but none actually popped out at me. I saw a few drones that were 'foldable', but they wouldn't completely fold, as the arms were in each other's way. So, here is my version of a foldable quadcopter!

Features:
All holes are made for m3 screws (Nylon 30mm m3 standoffs are recommended.)
Has strap mounts (26mm x 3mm hole) for strapping battery (or GoPro...?) to both bases.
On-board mounts: (x2) 30.5mm x 30.5mm (flight controller & ESC 4-in-1)
Motor mounts: 16mm x 16mm to 19mm x 19mm
Folded dimensions: ~180mm
Opened (flight) dimensions: ~330mm

Required:
8pc - m3x8mm screws
8pc - m3x40mm screws
8pc - m3 locknuts
32pc - m3 washers
Other- zip ties, loctite, electrical tape, heat shrink, straps. etc

Other:
If you have any questions or comments, feel free to leave them. I plan on updating any files if need be. If you find any errors or would like a specific thing added, let me know! Thank you so much, and enjoy your foldable quadcopter!

UPDATES:
March 12 2017: First version uploaded.
March 14 2017: Version 2. Modified arm mounting on both top and bottom bases. Redesigned motor arms (now less print time and material).

Printer:

FolgerTech Prusa i3 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

75% on arms and 25-50% on bases

I've been using the OhmEye Z isolators to help remove any Z banding on my MM2 printer.
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/3uyotd400xp2ef5/2pLnjCypcV/STLs/Z%20Isolators/ohmeye_mm2_isolator_release%202x.STL
I did notice that his one pad design puts it right under one of the screw holes possibly allowing the isolator to key into the hole and thereby reducing its effectiveness. I modified it to have two pads spaced between the screw hole.
Update: I have added a few other variations on the original. Personally I'm using version 3, as it has the bosses evenly across the leadscrew and out of the way of the lead nut bolt holes on the X axis.

description.text:
You may have seen my kickstarter project:

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1846150493/case-rap-the-3d-printer-you-can-bring-anywhere?ref=user_menu

unfortunately, I did not reach the target that I fixed...

Files can be found on pinshape:
https://pinshape.com/items/33215-3d-printed-case-rap-50

I expected to take one month off my job to "finish" the job: I wanted to improve the design and prepare accurate, complete, clear building instructions...

But I still can release my "uncomplete" job...

The desing is good enough to be sold as is...

About this 3d printer:

Sturdy, solid, foldable, portable, easy to use, easy to build for around 300$

You can bring it anywhere.

If you don't have that much room, you can put it away when non needed.

Auto bed leveling.

You can upgrade the printer you already have into a case-rap!

8x8x8 or 8x12x8.

(if you want to build 8x12x8, just add 4 inches (200mm to the width of the case rods and straps.)

And if I start selling more here... I may find the time to improve the design and the build instructions!

So about the stls

You will find them on pinshape:

https://pinshape.com/items/33215-3d-printed-case-rap-50

... Some of them needs to be printed more than once. I've written it in the file's name. (2x, 3-4x)

The following link is my "un" complete "un" accurate building instructions. Some parts of the instructions are up to date, some are not. You will find in this document the blueprints for the case, the buying list, etc. The wiring is even written in french, easier for me... But for the wiring anyways, it's just like any other reprap 3d printer, you'll find the informations at least 1000 other places on internet.

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1y-3R-m18U3UdnwEQelUpAg4mGpOAPGpT8YfpPk8awg0/edit?usp=sharing

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bf7uXg3lzJg&t=5s

Printer:

case-rap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm layer height

Infill:

40%

Notes:

For the x carriage, I suggest to print in abs so that it resists more to heat, but pla is ok... You'll have to clean some "in design" support material for this part.

For all other parts, print and use!

I started with a mendel 90 That I've put into a box....
It was too big and heavy.

So I decided to start the design all over.

I'ts been 2 years I'm working on it. I've build 12 up to now. I improved it soo much!

description.text:
---UPDATE---MARCH-31-2017---
Changed the description to describe use of two 28BYJ-48 steppers geared for ~2048 steps per revolution. Turned out the extra torque is often needed when winding, had to help it by hand to often with two of the 513 step per revolution versions, and even worse with only one of the 513 step per revolution version.
--END-UPDATE--

---UPDATE---March-15-2017---
I updated the C source for the Raspberry Pi controller program, now easier to use.
--END-UPDATE--

This is a simple winder powered by a Raspberry Pi, requires also 2 - 28BYJ-48 5 volt stepper motors and a ULN2803 darlington array.

This uses keyboard input to adjust the speed of the stepper motor attached to a Raspberry Pi computer. Once you get the speed as close as possible to the rate of extrusion on your filament making extruder you will not have to adjust it as often.

This is a lot better than hand winding, and a lot more reliable than getting laser diodes and sensors to line up perfect every time (like the auto-winders do). Also this takes very little electricity.

As filament extrusion speed is not a constant, and will very in unpredictable ways you will still need to make an adjustment to the speed every now and again.

Even though just finished on the day of this posting, I have already put this to use.

Printer:

HomeMade Custom.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

Between 15% and 25%, honeycomb.

Notes:

Print hot and slow for best results. Small enough parts for almost all printers, no more than 90x110 mm. Can be printed even on something as small as a ToyRep.

Use PLA for best results, with a print temperature of between 210 and 220 degrees (depending on printer).

Some quick instructions for assembly:
-The spool ends go into the ends of the spool, tight fit as they turn the spool.
-The square rods go inbetween the two sides. Print the main part twice to get all parts.
-The stepper adaptor goes into the holes by the spool slot in the sides, you need two, one for each side.
-The stepper motor is held to the adaptor by the small round pegs, again two, one for each side.
-Filimant feeds between the two cross braces infront of the spool.

The adapter is needed, so you can use this as a spool holder after you have made your filament. The spools hold 0.25KG of filament, you can print multiple spools, remember each should have its own spool ends so that they are not removed and continue to fit tight.

Hook the stepper motor up to the ULN2803, with the ULN2803's four used inputs going to pins 33,35,37,39 of the Raspberry Pi IO header, these are GPIO pins 6,13,19,26.

BE CAREFUL. It is possible to cause damage to your Raspberry Pi, Stepper, person, electrical, etc, so take care not to cause such damage.

You will need a Raspberry Pi running Raspbian Linux with WiringPi installed (installed by default in the desktop distro). The controller source code is included.

You will also need two 5 volt 28BYJ-48 stepper motors, preferably with the 64 to 1 gearbox, these are fairly common, and I purchase mine for $1.75 US each from Amozon (they are 2 for $3.50 US). You will want to use only the 64 to one geared, as the lowered geared (like the 16 to one) do not provide quite enough torque, learned the hard way.

To power the motors a ULN2803, ULN2003, or other driver that can directly handle unipolar steppers is required. Make sure it is just a driver as the control pulses come from the Raspberry Pi GPIO. Wire the two motors on the same outputs, having the order of the control wires reversed on one relative to the other so it runs the opisite direction in lock step with the first (though the power wire still goes to the 5V supply).

This is a protection module for the Baofeng UV-5R.

It's intent is to cover the transmit button and volume knobs so it can be put in a bag. (The software keypad lock handles the front buttons). I use this when rock climbing.

There is also a piece to protect the lapel mic port from strain or disconnection.

You will need two M2.5 screws to screw in where the clip normally goes.

v2 has some upgrades, still a WIP but leaving old files. I had issues printing the rounded portion around the volume knob on my printer so I just went for a square bridge.

print_settings.Printer:: Shayper Bot (Home built Prusa I3 Derivative)

description.text:
The title says it all, this is a speed feed for the Dye Rotor that you print out of Ninjaflex or other flexible material. This was one of those projects I was really looking forward to "taking a shot at" when I got my printer up and running, and I was not disappointed with the results. I'm not a "regular" paintballer, but I've used it several times throughout a full day of play and it has held up much better than I would have thought. The one in the pictures is the one I've been using, and besides some paint residue left over from splatter its physical condition is perfect.

It took a couple tries to reach the perfect balance between rigidity and size of the "fingers" so that a pod of paint would go in without a problem but would still keep the paint from falling out when the Rotor is tilted sideways or upside down. I think at this point I've achieved a good balance with the print settings I've included.

Printer:

Shayper Bot (Home built Prusa I3 Derivative)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I included the .ini file for cura users who want to use my exact settings for this print

The most critical settings for success are:

-.4mm shell thickness
-10% fill
-20mm/s print speed
-I would suggest a Brim of 10 at least for good bed adhesion
-Turn off retraction
-230 degrees Celsius print temperature
-Use a high travel speed for your printer (Mine is slow you might want to turn it up)
-Initial layer line width 100%
-The print fan will probably help, although my settings for the fan in the .ini file are probably not great. I don't think I used the fan for this print so you may want to adjust those to suit your printer.

Clean Up

I would suggest using a flush cutter to clean up any stringing left over.

title: E3D V6 Dual Hotend and integrated layer fan - like the prusa i3

description.text:
this modification is designed to be used for E3D V6 dual extrusion.
the nozzle offset is 32mm - I think that differs from the available modular x-axis-carriages.

minimum required is 30.5mm offset - while the required offset of the heatbreak in my case is 31.0mm - and then they touch together! you can turn the hotend of course by 90 degrees.

the right fan duct is widen by 5mm because the openbuild wheel needs space. that's why the airbox is extended to the new fan's outer edge. To not hit the x-axis extrusion profile my hotends were shift forward by 5mm. your x-axis carriage could require a modification in case of collision!

If you don't have any problems with spacing you can use the normal part without the expansion - airbox is same as the left one.

And finally there is a small spacer and carriage for the SN04-N that I'd lilke to have as near as possible to the hotends. Sensor height is adjustable without to dissemble the hotends

I actually don't plan to edit these parts. But I don't know if I will need to do later. I have prepared my own version of an dual e3d v6 convertion of my tevo tarantula for future. I'm still running on the dual chimera extruder.

made a bridge to the modular x-axis-carriage by thingirob.
look at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2265140

Update 2017-04-23:
Integrated fans hex-nut is a bit higher then the pocket allowed
was 2,25mm and now is 3,25mm
Old version would fit with low profile hex nut (DIN 439 / ISO 4035), current version fits with standard M4 nut.

fixed the right air box due to a mismatch. a small area was 1mm too high

2017-09-14
woohoooo ... attention.

the fan would not crash into the acrylic, but now with the upper v-slot wheel of the z-axis.
that depends on the used printer of course. with a stock tarantula e.g. I edited the module of the modular x-carriage to lower the full setup by 4mm down to bed.

have a look at the setting with the tevo acrylic part: the fan would crash into the acrylic, in this case the carriage needs to move further at least 3.5mm to the front - a mod that I would apply on the modular carriage. On a printer with steel rods instead of extrusion profiles it could and / or will be very different to the tevo tarantula e.g. and will fit without modifications to see at the image below

Because the upper description of the resulting issue on my tevo tarantula I have moved the carriage that holds the 2 E3DV6 hotends forwards by 4mm. Next what would cause a problem is the screw that holds the fan. replace the M4x18 by a M4x18 screw with a low profile head, that gives round about 1.3mm.

Finally the working area of the heated bed in x-axis is reduced to something at 174-177 mm in dual extrusion mode.
What it means to the y-axis to shift the hotend so much I will have to find out
Interested and you already have the modular x carriage by thingirob? follow this link to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2265140 right fan and the wheel, captured on september 14th

I've been using this direct drive (gearless) extruder with 3 mm ABS for about 6 months now and lately with PLA . I took the original Sells Mendel extruder and split it into two in order to use a spring to apply tension on the idler. The advantage of this extruder over the newer MK7 designs that use less plastic is that you can print the whole extruder except for the hobbed bolt or MK7 gear. 
I made two versions: One uses the MK7 pinch wheel and the other uses an M8 hobbled bolt that's been cut and drilled to mount on the motor shaft. The advantage of the smaller diameter 8mm bolt/rod is that it can apply more force to the filament.
It can surely go faster if 1.75 mm filament is used. The design for the hobbed bolt should work for 1.75 mm filament if a MK7 gear drive is used instead.
I've also included a 40 mm fan bracket.

There are built-in support that must be drilled with a 4 mm drill idler mounting bolts.
You'll need to either buy a MK7 pinch wheel. The better choice is to take an 8mm hobbed bolt, cut it, drill a 5 mm hole down the center and then tap across for a grub screw to fix it on the stepper motor shaft.

comments.text: For those asking about whether you can extrude 3mm feed fast enough with a direct drive NEMA 17, the answer is yes. Paired with a good hot end like the J-Head Mk-V that requires little force, I can extrude up to 160 mm/s of 3mm ABS feed through a 0.35 mm nozzle using a drive that's around 6.5-7 mm diameter.

comments.text: There is one advantage of this extruder over a wade style extruder. I've never stripped a filament since the motor runs out of torque before that happens. With a Wade styl extruder, it's very difficult to adjust the stepper controllers to limit the torque. With a lower gear ratio, perhaps you'll strike a more optimal balance.

comments.text: With a 0.5 mm Budascnozzle, I can print ABS with the 8 mm bolt at 0.4 mm layer thickness reliably at a print speed (feed rate) of at least 60 mm/s using the Marlin firmware. I typically print parts that are 100 mm long/wide so I'm sure it's getting up to that speed. I'd like to print much faster than that but in my experience, the infill gets thinner in the middle due to extruder lag using either Sprinter or Marlin.

title: 7" Range Hood Damper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I just installed a new range hood. The new hood did not come with a damper so I bought one made out of sheet metal. It was awful. Any advantage I had in buying a new quiet range hood was nullified by constan ting, ting, ting of the metal damper! Arggh!

So then I thought "what if I made a damper and printed it?" Ah hah, a new 3D printing project! I was extremely pleased with the results.

It is unlikely that I will ever print more than one of these and it's not the sort of thing that most people are going to need but I'm uploading it here on the chance that it might help someone else with a similar problem.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.350mm or finer

Infill:

20% Cubic

Notes:

Printed on a Prusa i3 MK2. I used ABS for this project. (Scale up by 101% for shrinkage.) PLA or PETG can be printed at size.

Print one base, one ring, and two flaps. If your range hood accommodates 3-1/4-in x 10-in ductwork, you may have to print the wings to cover the wide hole.

Assembly

This design uses thin stiff wire for the flap hinges. I had some spare 15ga. bicycle spokes that I used, but a suitable diameter of music wire would work (available in hobby shops.)

Cut the wires to length and insert in the holes in the base and flaps.

Slide the ring down over the wires to keep them in place. (You may wish to glue the ring if you want to make it permanent.

Customization

My particular range hood is a GE model JVX5360SJSS. This design can be customized for other hoods with 7" diameter ducting by modifying the design to place the holes in other locations (or you could print it as is and drill new holes in the plastic.

My range hood could also use 3-1/4-in x 10-in duct and the hole in the top of the rang was a combination of both types. This necessitated design some "wings" that screwed down over the part of the hole not covered by the damper. You may not need these parts depending upon the design of your range hood.

description.text: This is a keychain modeled after a Dadge Caliber.

Note: The files here are placeholders and may or may not work. For the latest files, please download from https://github.com/AxMod3DPrint/Drakon-Extruder

If you would like to purchase the SLS Printed version of the Drakon it is available at https://www.axmod3dprint.com/shop/drakon-extruder-175-sls/

The Drakon Extruder

Reliability, Performance, Power

The Drakon has 3:1 gear reduction, fully FDM 3D Printed to keep costs down while performing as well as an extruder at 2-3 times the cost. The Gear ratio means that you’re able to use smaller, lighter motors while keeping the same pushing force as a standard non-geared extruder. For direct drive systems this means a lighter carriage, with less inertial mass, improving print quality. For Bowden systems running a standard sized motor means the Drakon becomes a power house of an extruder with all the power you’ll ever need to get your filament where it needs to go. In both Direct Drive and Bowden configurations you get the reliability and piece of mind to know that it’s not your extruder that’s going to fail.

Resolution

By increasing the gearing to 3:1, this triples the resolution, which can mitigate filament being extruded in pulses at slow speeds, which can result in a wavy surface finish, to give you a smooth surface finish. Note: This will not help other mechanical issues such as Z Wobble or Z Banding.

Materials

The Drakon has a fully supported filament path, which means it can print anything from flexibles, Carbonfills, metalfills and the hardest of filaments and beyond.

Universally easy to use

The Drakon strips down quickly with no need to remove the motor from it’s mounting, loosen the 3 bolts and just remove it from it’s mount. Remove the 8mm nut and bushing and that’s it, highly easy to maintain, should you need to take it apart for any reason. The Tensioner window allows you to easily see and set the tension quickly and precisely with no fuss. Easily mounted on a Direct Drive system as well as a Bowden.

Assembly Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jO8r4zXFYHI

Demo

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O43gTT2txT4

Initially it only works with 1.75mm filament, but the 3mm will be available soon.

comments.text: Taken a quick look, not the best idea with the Drakon, though as it will lose some rigidity in the body. This was an issue I noticed with the NSTT, hence the cover also supporting the main bolt on the Drakon. You may not have noticed, but when the idler pushes against the main drive bolt/shaft there is a small amount of flex, over time this can cause weakness. I've run about 3-400 hours since the first working Drakon iteration and supporting the shaft with the cover reduces the likelyhood of fatigue in the plastic alongside keeping the shaft straight, (which is another issue I had with the NSTT).

comments.text: Weight ? Performance ? How do you mount it on a carriage or is it just Bowden ? Any video in operation ?  What do you gain compared to a direct extruder using the same NEMA 17 motor ???
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I'll update weight and performance later on. How you mount it is up to you, it'll mount like the E3D Titan, so both Direct Drive and Bowden (there's an extrusion bowden mount on the Github). Direct drive on 1.75mm you can drop down to a NEMA17 pancake motor with the gearing and end up as if using a standard NEMA17. You also increase your steps/mm offering extra extrusion resolution. Bowden, with a full sized motor, you get the extra torque which helps immensely.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Did you measure the torque required ? How about backlash and excessive force required with printed gears ?
comments.author: AxMod3DPrint

comments.text: No Torque meter so no, if your printer is well enough configured you will not get backlash or have excessive force issues.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: So you make things without measures, study ... ? Backlash of the extruder is easy to feel. The Wade design on which these are base was fine years back when not much was available, now it is totally outdated, parts too big, too heavy, poor gear finish.
comments.author: AxMod3DPrint

comments.text: Also as a note - http://www.axmod3dprint.com/images/drakon_gear.jpg they can come out very clean if your settings are right and your printer and slicer is well configured.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I cannot feel any backlash in my printed parts. Frankly, if you don't like it, ignore the design and you have a right to your opinions. However, before you start putting the design down, print it and try it, then come to a conclusion. The gears have very tight tolerances and mesh really well. Also, just for reference, the large gear is 36mm in diameter.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: In addition, I think backlash is a non-issue with extruders anyway.  Backlash only appears when the direction changes at the beginning of a retraction and then again when the direction changes back and you start feeding the filament back (the un-retraction?).  Since you really don't care about the exact absolute position of the filament when it's retracted, the two backlash events don't matter for all practical purposes.
comments.author: AxMod3DPrint

comments.text:
I tried printed gears months ago and although the finish was better than what I see here, I gave up considering it was a dead end. They require extra force to turn and just a small piece of plastic lodged in a gear will block them. And difficult to clean.
And I don't see how you adjust the gears for minimal play. If true, an other error.
comments.author: AxMod3DPrint

description.text:
I figured that I would create a new style of spinner that I haven't seen on this site. The center ring is held in place by the 4 screws. This one uses (4) 1/4" nuts, (4) 1/4"x1" screws and one 608 bearing.

This design is a little thicker and heavier than a normal spinner, but it's still manageable. The center ring is 11.5 mm tall as well (ball bearing is 7mm). The ring has 4 recessed areas so that the screws will go into and help hold the center ring in place. The outer piece is 11.5mm thick. I made it that way so that the screw heads wouldn't stick out too far.

This design is about 3" in diameter.

The design is in two pieces so you can print the center ring a different color if you choose.

description.text:
Buy it on Etsy! https://www.etsy.com/listing/505538516/nintendo-switch-portable-folding-stand?ref=shop_home_active_1

Update2: I tweaked the design a bit so it's taller. The bottom of the Switch now sits about a half inch higher off the table than before. This allows more room for the charging plug to prevent strain on the cable.

Update: I have added a new center piece called Switch Stand Center Foldable. This piece has two hinges of differing height, which allows you to fold the arms inward. The center piece is also a bit wider than the original, so the arms can fold completely within the width of the center.

This portable Zelda-themed charging stand is the perfect solution to a common issue with the Nintendo Switch. This stand features:
-Fold-flat design that fits into the same footprint as the Switch, meaning you can pack it into your travel case with your Switch!
-60 degree angle gives ideal viewing position
-Play your Switch while charging! Charging cable can be run through the front or out the back of the stand
-Wide base gives it a lot of stability
-Simple three-piece assembly. The hinge pins are made from 1.75mm filament. Just cut a piece and slide it through the hinge holes. Can also be disassembled by sliding the filament back out.

Note: Cut the hinge pin filament at an angle to help it slide through the hinges. You will likely need a pair of pliers to feed it through.

description.text:
The Collapsable Filament Reel Holder by PushPlastic (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1647784) doesn't play nice with the existing spool holder for the Wanhao i3 and its variants.

I remixed AzzA's Z Extension brackets to include a spool holder for these PushPlastic spools. I just had their 200g sample spools and this spool holder worked great, I don't know how well it would work with a full 1kg spool.

There's a stopper on one side, and I'm just using a ziptie on the outside to prevent the spool from falling off. It's not the most elegant solution, but it does the job.

This is a remix of the Pi Bookmark by astoit.

I wanted to print some handouts for my 13y granddaughter for her class on Pi day (3/14/2017) and figured this would not only be celebratory for Pi day but also a functional item. However, the original was rather large and the book tab was a tad on the thick side.

I thinned down the tab to 800 mils so it would be fairly thin and would easily divide into my 0.2mm layer height yielding 4 layers. I have included the original sized Pi with shortened marker tab.

I created a second model where the Pi and tab were sized down to about 60% the original height/width. I can easily get 30 on the build plate now. And they are small enough for kids to use in novels and school books both.

I printed mine using MakerGeeks PETG for its flexibility as well as layer bonding strength. I pushed the layer extrusion multiplier up to 1.25 so it would lay down nice fat lanes since it was going to be so thin.

After printing, allow the bed to cool sufficiently! This is a thin print and will distort (especially if printing with ABS) if you don't allow the bed to cool enough. I printed with PETG with bed at 80c. I tried removing samples at 60c and 40c and both distorted so I allowed the bed to cool to near room temp and they popped off with no distortion.

title: Open Source Minifig - Ghost Ver 4.2 -  April 2014

description.text:
• Update 10/20/2014: I uploaded a new STL for the head. I think it was missing. I'm in the process of double checking this whole figure and updating him. Look for an new version in a few days....
  • Update 4/19/2014: I enlarged the hip connection .5mm. This should tighten up the hip joint.
    Update 4/4/2014: I just realized I had the wrong torso file in here. I've fixed it. The arms and hips should fit 10 times better now. Thanks.
    This is the latest version of my open source figures.
    I've deleted the older versions to alleviate any confusion. Plus, this guy blows them away...
    This dude is a "game changer". His joints are bomb-proof solid and a world of difference better than the last version. They actually have a split built in for flexibility and are covered for aesthetics.
    This model can easily be tweaked to work with PLA or ABS. This latest version is optimized for ABS but can work with most materials.
    Print as is - then sand the ball joints down if they are too tight.
    OPEN SOURCE - The way this model excels as "open source" is that the joints are simply 4mm ball sockets. This enables you to make your own accessories or tweaks. Also the hands are 3.5mm holes so anything with a round peg about 3.4~3.5mm in diameter will fit in his hands securely.
    All the accessories from my previous models should work with this new figure as well.
    Please comment and let me know how it prints on your various machines.

Print the Hip Joint at 100% fill - Great suggestion from one of the Makers.
I print everything else at 10% with walls of 4. I also print with support material, hence why the torso is upside down. The inside joint on the torso prints best upside down.

comments.text:
Open Source is a vague term. I can limit the distro or give away whatever I like if I designed it. I was just trying to put together a total package for anyone that might want to use this a base for their own line of figures. I wasn't limiting what I was originally giving away. 123D design is on it's way to becoming the "go to" software for newcomer's to 3D "printable" designs. Packaging a huge list of files into one package would enable someone to design this model from scratch. I was just looking for a way to do that on top of the free design base.
I'm just fooling around with models of distribution and seeing what works and what folks dislike. Didn't mean to get anyone all worked up...

comments.text: Yeah, totally... I was just thinking of a way to enable folks to re-design or re-sell their own figures based on this model.  The STLs will always be there and free. The detailed and editable files for each little piece was what I was packaging. I was limiting the distro of those because you can pull them straight into Inventor or 123D and call them your own. title: LaForge Diversity V2 Module (Buttons) for Headplay HD Headsets

description.text:
The first version of the Headplays only had a 32 channel receiver with no diversity and no scanning. The receiver sensitivity also left much to be desired. Rangevideo also sells an easy plug-in to a 40 channel receiver but does not have the scanning feature.
The idea was to make the Laforge integration look as clean as possible.
It takes about a few hours to do all the work.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

This is totally worth the trouble :-)
You got this.

Where do I plug my modules in? Undo the four screws holding the headplays together in the corners. Carefully separate the top from the bottom. Loosen the 4 screws holding the display board. Be careful to not pull on any wires. Red: Mark which slot the module plug into. The plug next to it is the same size. Blue: Mark the wire with the signal name before cutting the connector off. You need Video, Audio, +5V, and one of the grounds. Pick your favorite. Extend the orgional RangeVideo reciever patch cable with a 4 wire of ribbon cable. The extra ground and the RSSI are not used. This is about how long the cables should be. Keep track of the signal wire before you heat shrink everything up Optional: Connect the newly cut cable to some spare servo wire so we can test the laforge modules before voiding the warranty. Pinout from the manual. Tie the audio lines together. the NC stand from not connected so we're not using them IT'S ALIVE! last chance to turn back before voiding the laforge warranty. The headplay warranty is long since lapsed. Check to see if the diversity is switching properly. Prep the main module. Cut off the pins flush to the plastic spacers. Then you can carefully wiggle off the plastic connector leaving a small nub of standoff to solder the wire to Cables soldered and use double stick tape to hold it in place. Plug in the white diversity cable and lay it where the blue is indicating. Then heatshrink the two cables together Prep the top plate and diversity module. Optional: Drill a small hole to allow the diversity module's led's to shine through. Patch up the hole left by the old receiver with some sandable putty. After sanding the putty flat. Paint with some model paint or just use a large enough sticker to cover up that ugly paint job :-\ Test fit the laforge diversity module in the hole where the old receiver used to be. Cut off this standoff because it's blocking our connector The blue parts shows where you should apply hot glue to hold the module in place. Cutting the headplay case. Use the bottom template on how big to cut the hole. Be careful not to cut all the way through. Hollow out just enough foam to put the back plate in. Take a small chunk out at a time Hole complete. It doesn't have to look pretty. If you accidentally cut to deep. You can glue it back with some E6000 glue. Cut a slot for the cable into the top of the headplays. Use the backplate as a template on where to put the cable slot. You want to put it close to the centerline of the top case. Test fit the back plate into your newly voided headplays. See what I did there ;-) heatshrink the diversity cable and the signal cable together to make it look neater. The cables fit into the slots cut out in the back plates. Test fit the buttons into the top plate. Make sure they're loose enough to push the buttons. Also test fit the laforge and everything should have very little play Check the fit of the module, you might need to tweak some dimentions. The board with the buttons should just rest up agains the bottom of the back plate. The spacers that go between the buttons should just touch the board. As you can see here there is a gap so those parts needs to be lengthened a bit. Tack some superglue the top plate to the bottom plate. Everything should line up. Check to make sure the buttons click properly. If not then take it apart and sand it until the fit is correct. Test fit. Make sure the wires lay flat into the cable guide and the case sits flush into the headplays. if not then you need to remove more material.

1) Plug in the diversity module
2) Plug in laforge main module and the power power cable into the headplay board
3) Screw headplay board to top mount
4) Reassemble headplay top plastic piece to foam housing
5) Insert laforge module housing into newly cut hole
6) reassemble headplays
7) Glue headplay module to the foam using E6000 adhesive. Lightly glue all 4 corners to make it easier to disassemble in the future.

YOU DID IT! NOW LET'S FLY! Googly eyes ++style_poi

description.text:
I was sitting with my son this afternoon watching him color in his Shrinky Dinks. When he was done, and they were all shrunk, he was having a hard time with the included paper holders as they either didn't fit at all or would fall over. He turned to me and said he wanted to make a holder that works so they all stand up like they should. He told me he had a plan...

My son is 6 years old and I said sure son. Let's go make this holder. He told me the base should be circular and have a slot in it for the Shrinky Dink to sit. So we measured a few of the shrunk Shrinky Dinks and came up with a good size base. We then measured the average depth and with those basics I sat him down at the computer. He has never really worked a computer before but I walked him through using the mouse and adding the basic shapes. About 15 minutes later, walking him through the software (Microsoft 3D Builder), he had his model. I never touched the mouse or keyboard. I told him how to save it then he loaded it up into XYZWare and pressed print. 15 minutes later he was the proud owner of his very first model.

I couldn't pry him away from the printer while it printed and the look on his face when it was done and it worked was priceless. Now that's a fun afternoon. I can't wait to see what he comes up with next

description.text:
See this at Sketchfab here: https://skfb.ly/66VYp

Havocraft. Space craft that wreaks havok on the enemy. With quad rainmakers, adaptable systems turret and stealth skin, Havocraft is happy to visit target rich environments. Digital sculpting, 3d models and creative geometry. The core of multi-dimensional visual arts. At Dabble Bird Models: http://www.dabblebird.com/models.html

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aPYh4XEMdh2

Took on a life of it's own.

This was originally a fractal art work that developed into fantasy art of a underwater ship with cat eyes as a photo manipulation. I extruded the shape in photoshop, then using boxes in tinkercad I cut away the extrusion until it was a basic shape. Then I furthered it by duplicating it and combing it back together, then back into tinkercad for weapons and dome, then in meshlab to cleanup , then to sketchfab.
But it's not over. I have to reduce it further for the Morphyre Pro 3d animator, to make moving video of it. Rather unorthodox, but that's how it is.

Contagion Assay Transport Vessel Cat-V. Fractal/photoshop. Extrusion of design was used to build the ship Havocraft by Dabble Bird Havocraft at Sketchfab

Havocraft at Sketchfab here https://skfb.ly/66VYp
For New Years!

Box Mod optimized for RX 2/3 by Wismec

description.text:
Here's the updated version of my Switch Joy-Con holder. I've removed any issues that should prevent it from needing any supports as well as addressed some gaps that confused some slicers. I also slimmed it up a bit, making it a bit more compact / travel friendly.

Essential print settings, make sure that you have at most a .4mm nozzle and set the nozzle size in the settings to .4mm ( default for some is .48 ). layer height and infill shouldn't really matter. No supports needed.

comments.text: The joycons also don't stay in place for me.  I figured out why and have modeled rails that work.  If you look at the switch with the joycon off you'll see that, from the top, there's 4.5mm of rail, then a 4.5mm gap, and then the rest of the rail.  The button you press on the back of the joycon to take it off the switch causes a little peg on the joycon to retract.  It's this peg that fits in the 4.5mm space and keeps the joyccon from just sliding off the switch.  Your controller needs this as well.

description.text: My family is a family of musicians. My husband asked for a pencil holder that could fit on a music stand or his tuba. So this was made. The larger circle that grips the tube of the music stand is 25mm and is slightly flexible. It should hold onto any tube that is 25mm or a little bit bigger. The smaller circle is 7mm and hold a standard #2 pencil. This was created using TinkerCad and you can obtain a copy of this object at https://tinkercad.com/things/c1O6ZPxl6Oe-tuba-pencil-holder
I've found that if you use a brim  you get better edges for this object, so print with a thin brim (I used 4mm) and remove after printing. The brim also lets this adhere to the print bed nicely.

title: Classic Game Station
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Classic Game Station Enclosure

This is an enclosure intended to be used with the Raspberry Pi Zero and MakerSpot Stackable USB Hub.

For background, assembly details, and additional information, check out:

http://www.classicgamestation.com

Notes:

You'll need to print the enclosure (either enclosure.stl or enclosure-anti-warping.stl) and cover.

Supports
  • The cover will probably need a small amount of support on the underside of the recessed screw hole.
  • The enclosure itself may need some support within the HDMI port opening (in the back) and/or the SD card slot on the side.
Warping / Curling

If you're printing in ABS (or other materials prone to warping), you may want to try enclosure-anti-warping.stl. The tabs can help prevent the corners from curling up, and are quite easy to remove after printing.

title: Phone Holder for NuVI mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My wife has a permanent (or nearly so) mount for a nüvi GPS receiver in her car. She asked me if I could come up with a way that she could use her cellphone for navigation (she's a fan of Waze) that used the existing mount.

I came up with a two part solution. One part connects to a NuVI disk mount. The other holds the phone. The two parts screw together. Being a two part design, it would be possible to create a new device holder that is attached to the NuVI mount and vice versa.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.200mm

Infill:

20% Cubic

Assembly

The two parts are joined by four 6-32x.375" screws (I used brass thumb-screws) and four 6-32 nuts.

Customization

If one just wanted nüvi compatible for a different holder, just print out the back part. And likewise, if one wanted the Galaxy S5 holder for another purpose, just print out the front part. By maintaining the hole pattern, new variations on this Thing can be created.

Compatibility

This holder was designed specifically for a Samsung Galaxy S5 phone with a thin case. It may or may not be compatible with other mobile devices/cases. Your mileage may vary.

title: 1978 Tomy Demon Driver Game Steering Wheel Replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a pretty obscure "thing", but I thought I'd post in case there is anybody with a damaged copy of this game from the late 70's that they'd like to repair.

Mine has been stored for many years and when I pulled it out I discovered that something had been sitting on top of it and had broken the plastic steering wheel (see 3rd photo).
I have seen them on Ebay like this too, so I guess it may be a common problem if they no longer have the box to store them in.

After measureing what was left of the original and modelling a replacement, I printed the 1st version as a single piece.
It printed well, but the support inside the cylinder part was a pain to get out.

For the second attempt I split the model to allow printing without support.
The two parts were simply bonded together after. This is the one in the photos.

I have supplied both versions, so choose whichever one you think will work best for you.

title: GT2 belt clamp for MendelMax & Prusa

description.text:
This is a derivative of the following file, https://github.com/prusajr/PrusaMendel/blob/master/source/belt-clamp.scad I replaced all hard coded dimensions with variables, so now it is fully parametric.
It is configured for GT2 belts but you can make it fit any belt and also modify the clamp size.
The clamp is asymetric which means you can adjust your GT2 belt tension in 1mm steps(belt pitch / 2) by rotating the clamp 180deg.
The belt width has been resized from 7 to 10mm to allow more room for adjusment to line up the belt with the pulleys.
Thickness has been reduced from 7 to 3mm.

title: X-CARVE Dust Shoe (NewBrit Design) - big hole

description.text:
• Update: 2017-04-15 : See below, updated parts.

Video's of it in action:

  • https://www.instagram.com/p/BTM8AcpgM1f/
  • https://www.instagram.com/p/BTxDf14AxJj/

This is a dust-shoe for the Inventables X-Carve. The main advantage it has is that the shoe is independent from router, allowing the router to move within it.

This is a remix of the design made by jzhvymetal, which he derived from an awesome dustshoe design by "New Brit Workshop". You can find his original youtube vid here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PUcAXgsdk3U
And the Inventables forum post for this design here:
https://discuss.inventables.com/t/fully-3d-printed-newbritt-dust-shoe/30026

On a side note, if you're looking for a single-piece 3d printable dust shoe, I have my own design here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1259385

jzhvymetal was kind enough to give me the cad files, which allowed me to modify the base to support my 2.5" line in Fusion 360. In addition, I modified it to accept a plexiglas window (cut on my X-Carve), so you can see the cutting action. If you don't want to deal with the plexi, just run some tape over both sides.

I've included stl's, f3d (fusion 360) and step files for the parts I modified: newbrit_base_bigHole.stl is my addition, everything else was made by jzhvymetal .
If you want to cut the plexi window, extract the cad files, and generate your toolpath.

  • UPDATE 2017-04-15: I found the "SIDE_LEFT.stl" and "SIDE_RIGHT.stl" prints would rub against bolts holding the z-gantry into it's channel, causing friction. Because of that, I modified those files to allow for ample space there, but not impact the design. Please find new side_right_channeled.stl / step & side_left_channeled.stl & step files. I've removed the original files from this page. The above picture is still with the old files.

Things I learned while putting this together:

You'll need:

  • A printer that can print something 9"x5" (size of the new base).
  • Four M5 x45mm bolts to put the arms and base together.
  • Four M5 nuts.
  • You can either use four more M5 x45mm bolts for the topblocks (you'll need to drill them out first), or four machine screws of a similar length (what I ended up doing).
  • The design has space for eight 3mm x 12mm magnets to help hold the shoe on. These are not required, but make it nice when screwing it in, an extra hand to hold things in place.
  • Some parts need sanding to make fit: The original wood design has some bevels the printed version does not.
  • The 'top back' piece is held in pace by the two M5 bolts holding in the X stepper: My bolts were just barely long enough, but I ordered two more at 20mm to make sure there'd be no chance of slip.
  • The brush it uses can be found here: https://www.mcmaster.com/#7900t5/=16g0r06
  • I used hot-glue to secure the magnets and plexi.

print_settings.Notes:: It should print real easy.

description.text:
Getting ready for Easter...
The wife put the original on our table and the scanner was setup so I threw it (gently) on to the turn table. I attempted to do a textured scan of this with the Einscan-S. A textured scan uses the gray scale of the capture and assigns color to it. It did okay with blue and green but not red. So the result looks like it's covered in algae... all green and blue. I uploaded only the stl version since the obj textured version was way too large.
Otherwise the scan came out pretty well and only needed 2 turns on the table; one upright and one on its back. No cleanup afterward was needed at all.

For the whole story of this thing and how i scanned it with the Einscan-S listen to the 3d Printing Today podcast: threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com. It's free, has gobs of interesting 3D Printing content and is listener supported... I,e., not ads or popups. If you are having tons-o-fun with your 3D Printer then you REALLY should have a listen!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

You'll need to print:
2x Blade and 2x Handle, or 2x Full Scissor
2x Flame Plate
1x Pivot Part 1
1x Pivot Part 2

When Assembling, the pivot points go through the blades and glue together. The flame plates cover the pivot points, but be careful not to glue the pivot point to the flame plates. There should be just enough room to glue the plates to the blades without getting glue on the pivot point.

The separated blade and handle version can be printed on a printer with a 120mm x 120mm build volume.

This is new version of the Crosslock Rubber band powered crossbow which will now be called the Glokbow.

the top is not manifold. i repaired it, and it printed well after that.
the left arm is badly mounted, because of the sideplate being too thin to be sturdy. id go back to your earlier design that had a plate only for the trigger mechanism.
the trigger mechanic is very good, but a pain in the arse to screw in mounts for gummi rings. also mounting holes should be in the design for easier positioning.
the holes for screws (that are printed in the body) should be wider.
i'd leave out the "iron sights" altogether.
comments.author: valravn

comments.text:
I've got an problem. Being new to 3d printing, I'm hoping that it's something obvious.
Every time I slice the top print, part of the right bow vanishes in the sliced version. Specifically,, the quarter-cylinder that where the bow attaches to the barrel. I've tried two different slicers (slic3r and a proprietary derivative), as well as loading the gcode into two different host programs (Repetier-host & a proprietary one that may be derived from it).
While I think I've worked around this (since moltenplastic provided the source, I just grabbed the other arm and mirrored it), I'm still curious as to what might be going on here.

comments.author: nrtay4

comments.text: Interesting. I was about to make something very similar in shape and function but was fighting to get a good trigger/string-release design. Looks like you have some kind of spring installed to make it work, or how do you reset the trigger-mechanism? And a retainer that holds the arrow/bolt in place when the bow is loaded needs to be added. Keep up the good work, looking forward to see how you improve it further.
comments.author: Protonite

comments.text: I hijacked the mechanism from an ancient design.  I looked at several old crossbows and extrapolated from there.  I am currently not using springs.  I am using several rubber bands that people with braces use.  These rubber bands stretch but return to their normal shape, and also do not deform as much as a rubber band under tension.  The shape of the mechanism and two rubber band's tension, one in the vertical and one in the horizontal, help to make the mechanism work.
comments.author: Protonite

title: GoPed Bigfoot Electric Scooter Conversion Parts

description.text:
I thought I would upload all the parts I use to convert so far a couple of old petrol GoPed Bigfoot scooters to electric. As well as these parts you clearly need a bunch of other stuff including metal brackets to mount the drive train and a bunch of electronics, which includes but is not limited to:

A 80-ish tooth and 11-12 tooth chain drive set plus chain, typically used for Mini-Moto and other scooters. I bought mine from Petrolscooter.co.uk.

A couple of Multistar 16ah 4S batteries which are arranged in series to product 8S of Lipo voltage (33-ish volts).

A Turnigy SK3 6374 192kv motor, this with the sprocket setup above is good for about 28mph. and will cover 20km range easily.

A VESC speed controller, the bracket here is for the 4.12 from Scramboards which has a heatsink. Other ESCs like the D-Luc from Turnigy work, but the VESC can operate the throttle in a current mode which is more like a traditional scooter throttle whereas a regular ESC is a bit wild.

Two hall effect thumb throttles, and an Arduino Nano to control it, contact me if you want the firmware for this.

A bunch of 10mm outer, 8mm inner LEDs for the rear light cluster and status LEDs etc. The N79AX from Maplin was what I used.

Loads of M5, M4, M8 and M10 bolts.

I may do a blog post on putting it all together if I have the time to do so, but the whole thing is pretty straightforward if you have some decent metalworking and electrics knowledge.

In terms of the parts provided here, this is a brief description of each:

4S 16ah Multistar Bracket Inner and Outer - These hold the two Turnigy batteries firmly against the bottom of the wooden deck and the inner bracket fits around the main chassis tube, you need one inner and two outers for a dual battery setup.

VESC Mount - This holds the VESC tightly and provides cooling to the heatsink as well as having a space in the back to accept a Bluetooth LE module for onboard telemetry to an iPhone or Android device.

SK3 Fan Cover - This has been published here before but is added here for completeness, it snaps onto the back of the SK3 motor to provide cooling across the windings as the motor is mounted sideways to the air flow.

Tailpipe Light Cluster - This holds three red LEDS and provides a nice neat solution to covering the tailpipe which used to be the exhaust and serves as a pathetic attempt to legalise the scooter.

Arduino Nano Cover - Provides a case for the Arduino and a backing for the status LED that is mounted into the top of the board for showing battery level etc, see here: https://youtu.be/mKAX4GPSQek .

XT90 Fob Cover / XT90 Switch Holder - I turn the GoPed on and off using an XT90 which switches the voltage of the batteries through to the rest of the gear, this provides a mechanism to hold the XT90 and provides a nice neat fob for the XT90 plug.

8S XT60 Charge Point - This terminates an 8S balance socket which I used to mate the two 4S balance plugs to a single 8S balance socket as well as an XT60 connector for the main charge point. On mine this is always energised (not controlled by the XT90) so the scooter can be charged whilst switched off.

I appreciate that all this stuff may not be the most useful without a step by step guide but hopefully come people will be able to use some of it to make their own widowmakers. :-)

author: nickcrow

description.text:
A modular case for the raspberry pi, print a top and bottom to suit whatever you want to mount your pi to, and whatever top you want so you can cover/see your pi.
The four sides join to form hinges - this makes it easy to bolt them all into a line of four, fold it around the pi, then fix. I experimented with supporting the pcb from above and below, but this design causes the pcb to flex far far less.

Print the four sides, then print whatever top and bottom you want to fit (i'll upload these soon if i haven't). Use 4 m3 bolts to secure everything (I used cable ties in the photos because I didn't have 4 bolts long enough.

title: Bemis Toilet Seat Anchor for One-piece Ceramic Toilets (Kohler)

description.text:
Bemis "Easy Clean & Replace" toilet seats have hinges with snap-on twist-clips that attach to anchoring bolts with specially shaped heads. The product packaging claims that the toilet seat will fit all manufacturer's toilets.

However, it turns out that the included fasteners won't work with Kohler one-piece ceramic toilets because of its unique design which prevent the use of the specially shaped anchoring bolts. (It's possible that this may also work with Toto toilets with a similar issue; but I have no way to check.)

I could have purchased online a "HK36 Hardware Kit" which does the same thing for $5 + $9 S/H... But then I'd have to wait for the parts to arrive. So out comes the calipers and CAD software -- and the problem is solved!

You can print these for a few dime's worth of plastic and have them in a couple of hours.

Plus, you get to further justify to your spouse why you bought that 3D printer. Win-win.

description.text:
A simple adapter i designed for mounting a cheap Chinese tape binder to a Husqvarna Viking Sapphire 835.

I don't know the first thing about sewing machines or tape binders, i just designed it for my wife, and she's happy with it :)

Printer:

Original Prusa I3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

200 microns

Print it standing on the flat edge, with supports enabled.

This is the new AP Orbit Skill Toy - a remix of an old toy that was laying around in my room. Its based on 3 (or maybe more) spheres and one cord. The middle sphere is free to move across the cord. So its possible to perform a bunch of cool tricks and moves with it as you can see in this video: https://youtu.be/GJPR9KLJnHQ

What do I have to print?

  • 2x APOrbitMid
  • 4x APOrbitEnd

I use 2mm paracord.

If you have questions or problems with this design - write a comment - I try to respont.

Also check out my Begleri Skill Toy: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2148389

UPDATE V2

  • new version for US dimes
  • new Design for the End-Balls to have more room for the cord to fit in

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Its up to you 0.2 - 0.08

Infill:

15% works fine

May you have to do a little bit of sanding but it should pressfit fine.
To give it a bit more weight there are some holes in the design for 1-Euro-Cents (4 for each sphere)
This design was developed with Fusion360

description.text:
UPDATE 16/05/2017: Added a version with no center supports as requested in comments.

UPDATE: V4 is now a bit more crash-resistant, has bigger screw holes, and has proper orientation for printing without rotating.

This design is made to match for the most part the original protectors of furiousfpv's moskito 70 (one of the smallest brushless fpv quad).

It weights about 6g according to Cura, roughly the same as the original one. True printed protector weight its about 0.7g more, and a bit more fragile (on PLA), but perfectly usable to keep propellers safe and resist light to moderate crashes.

Printer:

Hephestos 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

<=0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The model is quite small and fragile, so it is recommended to make it solid, either with 100% infill or using >6 perimeters (with 0.2mm extruder).

Print with the big circular protectors facing down. Support is recommended for a good finish, although it is possible to print it directly. Adhesion might be tricky as that side is sightly curved for better aerodinamic.

About screw holes

The model is made with all the needed holes to mount it, with the correct size if the printer is capable of such precision.

With some printers it may need re-drilling on the center holes (on V3), as i prefer a tight fit.

Remember to remove the support material in the intersection of the circles aswell, not only from the arms that connect to the frame.

description.text:
Based off of Drew Petitclerc's UP! Extruder Modification  
Modified the existing Extruder to fit an UP Plus. I added the the mounts for the fan shroud and the fan itself. I also modified the heater board mount to fit the new board. I printed everything out of PLA on the UP including the Pressure arm and the holding block and have about 20 hours printing on them so far. Instead of using a Spring plunger i substituted a Screw and Nut which i glued to the extruder and then found a pen spring of suitable size. This allows me to change the pressure quiet easily which has com in handy while printing Flexible filament so far.  
This is still a WORK IN PROGRESS as i did have to remove some material with a dremel to make everything operate smoothly. I will be updating theSTL to reflect these changes soon.

description.text: Key ring designed by Chloe at St. Mary's University Twickenham.

I noticed that when I put a different filament guide on top of the smooth rods that the filament would enter the extruder assembly at an odd angle. I designed this guide to stop the filament from entering the extruder assembly at an odd angle and to stop it from slipping off the hobbed bolt and bearing.
simply hook the curved part around the nylon spacer near the hole in the top of the extruder assembly and rest the long arm part on the other side of the hole leading to the hobbed bolt

I built a crystal radio receiver. http://joshburker.blogspot.com/2014/01/building-crystal-radio-receiver.html I built and printed this model instead of using a cardboard toilet paper tube for my radio coil because the plastic offered more strength. Also, my Thing-O-Matic cannot print tall enough to print the tube as a single model. I printed the tube in two parts and glued the ABS plastic together. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/0KXg4ibAaxK You could combine the two models to make a single tube for printing. Or you could build your crystal radio with a toilet paper roll. The important thing is that you build a crystal radio.

Printed in ABS on a Thing-O-Matic at 5% infill. Glued with Testor's model glue along top edges of the models. Instructions on how to build a crystal radio are available on the Internet. I wrote a narrative of my build with a parts and tool list. http://joshburker.blogspot.com/2014/01/building-crystal-radio-receiver.html

author: J0rrr

description.text: Here's a simple bracket for an adjustable spark gap for all your high-voltage needs.  This picture shows a DC arc of about 25 kV, but I have run my HV DC supply up to 50 kV by increasing the gap space.

Should be pretty self explanatory, simply print out and add your metal parts!  I recommend using some PTFE (aka Teflon--the white parts in the picture) as insulators if you plan to allow continuous arcing for more than a minute or so since the metal will become very hot and begin to melt the printed piece.  You can purchase PTFE in many shapes and sizes from McMaster.  No need for the insulators if you just plan to run it briefly.  Ideally you would use tungsten for the electrodes, but stainless will still last quite a long time.
As always, don't play with high-voltage unless you know what you're doing (but you'll obviously need a lot more than just this to be dangerous.)

comments.text: What are you using as a power source for this thing?
comments.author: Iamstu

comments.text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FRrLJe4J8uwhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v...
comments.author: Iamstu

comments.text: In this picture I used an adjustable 1-50kV DC power supply I built from a monitor flyback, an adjustable oscillator circuit, and a multi-stage Cockroft-Walton multiplier stack.  The output won't rise above a given level which is related to the breakdown of air across the gap.  If the gap is adjusted to be larger then a high voltage is reached at the power supply output before breakdown.  If you were to supply High Voltage AC of about 20kHz or greater you will get a beautiful purple (nitrogen) plasma.

description.text: A ring for attaching the Hoodman HoodLoupe 3.0 to a digital camera using 1/8" or smaller elastic cord.

-Print the ring flat side down with solid infill
-Clean the part and remove any sharp edges
-Remove the wrist strap ring from the HoodLoupe
-Slide the attachment ring over the eyepiece with the elastic cord in place as seen in the picture
(any stretchable cord material that fits into the recesses in the ring can work: rubber bands, bungee cord, o-ring material...)
-Stretch the cords over the front of the camera to secure the HoodLoupe
(Each camera will have a different placement that works best if using solid loops of cord, tied loops or cord locks)

description.text: Lesson focuses on how bridges are engineered to withstand weight, while being durable, and in some cases aesthetically pleasing. Students work in teams to design and build their own bridge Bridges must have a span of at least 14 inches and be able to hold the most weight. Students are encouraged to be frugal, and use the fewest amount of filament/supplies while still achieving their goals. Students then evaluate the effectiveness of their own bridge designs and those of other teams, and present their findings to the class.
NGSS

Objectives:
Learn about civil engineering. Learn about engineering design. Learn about planning and construction. Learn about teamwork and working in groups.

Lesson/Duration:
Day 1:
Discuss types of bridges and have a Civil Engineer come in to discuss bridges with students
Day 2 and 3:
Have students used given links, books and other materials to research types of bridges and their success rates
Days 5-7:
Have students construct and try bridge prototypes, making changes when necessary
Day 8:
Final weigh in - test bridges and have other teams rate bridge
Day 9:
Reflections Possible Extensions:
Have students document their process with a video (we use SeeSaw)
Students could make a presentation on why the city should build their bridge (full presentation, persuasive essay or imovie trailer)
Writing Activity: Write an essay or a paragraph about how new engineered materials have impacted the design of bridges over the past century. Gumdrop Bridges
gumdrop bridges

Prep/Materials:
Access to internet to share research sites with students
Print Challenge sheets
Access to various materials and 3D modeling software It is recommended that you print the linked bridges as examples
10 days

It is recommended that you print the linked bridges as examples.  Also, have materials present for students to see bridges, research and compare bridges.  Decide on a weight type to test bridges-- we used small weights one year and pennies another... Weight type should depend on how many materials you are giving your students to build.

Extended Research Links
TryEngineering

TryEngineering
Sydney Harbor Bridge History

Syndey Harbor Bridge
Building Big - Bridges

Building Bridges Online Shared reading:
Galloping Gertie

Galloping Gertie
